messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Cheap but Usefull katana
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, Incredibly good answer.. Thanks buddy, i think i m going for the paul chen ppractical katana. best regards, Fred Leon ... From: nihontochicken To:
messages.messageBody:
Hi,

Incredibly good answer.. Thanks buddy, i think i'm going for the paul chen ppractical katana.

best regards,

Fred Leon
----- Original Message -----
From: nihontochicken
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, February 24, 2004 6:06 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Cheap but Usefull katana


I'm not into tameshigiri, but did buy a Paul Chen Practical katana on
Ebay for $130 including shipping. I felt I got quite a bit for the
money. Though the blade is of mill steel, it shows fine wisps of
hada (sunagashi). I have read articles by guys in the know who
tested some blades, unfortunately don't remember where, so you'll
have to do a web search to dig them out. I think I remember the Chen
and the United Cutlery swords got good marks in the cheapie
category. For sure, stay away from the cheap stainless steel blades;
they can be brittle and fracture on impact, launching the free end to
who-knows-where. The drawbacks that I can relate re the Chen
Practical Katana include the following. 1. The tsuka is non-
removable (in fact, the nakago has a kink in it to help insure it
stays inside the tsuka); the tsuka must be destroyed to get it off
the blade, and any replacement tsuka may not be removed by just
sliding it off, due to the nakago kink. 2. The shape of the blade is
actually fairly good in that it is reasonably appropriate, regular
and lacking in waves/ripples; however, it is "flat polished", i.e.,
little or no niku (clamshell curve from the shinogi to the ha).
Thus, it should cut rather well, but be more susceptible to chipping
than it would if more traditionally shaped. Even with these
reservations, I feel the Chen katana is a good deal for the money,
particularly if you can get a good discount on Ebay. FWIW.

NC

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Cheap but Usefull katana
messages.msgSnippet: ... Not too many of us are using swords like this for cutting. I think with swords at these levels, you re running a major risk of injuring yourself through
messages.messageBody:
<fred@...> writes:

> http://shopthroughtheages.com/unitedcutleryswords.html
> http://shopthroughtheages.com/paulchenswords.html
> http://shopthroughtheages.com/inhouseswords.html

Not too many of us are using swords like this for cutting.

I think with swords at these levels, you're running a major risk of
injuring yourself through equipment failure.

From what some of the guys write, you may be better off with the stuff
at www.bugei.com and/or ask your questions there.

- darcy

messages.subject: Cheap but Usefull katana
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, I m newbie on this. I started practicing kenjutsu and iaido with great effort and i love it, Well i m want to buy my first katana, and i know you already
messages.messageBody:
Hi, I'm newbie on this. I started practicing kenjutsu and iaido with
great effort and i love it, Well i'm want to buy my first katana,
and i know you already got many of this questions but here is it.

I'm looking for a cheap but useful katana to start with, i have not
much budget so i'm trying to look something around $100 more or less
(i can try to afford more). I find this katanas but because i'm
newbie i don't know which one are good.

http://shopthroughtheages.com/unitedcutleryswords.html
http://shopthroughtheages.com/paulchenswords.html
http://shopthroughtheages.com/inhouseswords.html

I don't know how the quality is or if they work for what i do.

Right now my choice is the Paul Chen's Practical katana at $149
Or the leather katana from united cutlery.. (also what do you think
about the full tang?) cheaper but if it works it's ok for me. I want
to start with something that feels real, i practice a lot with the
bokken but you all know its weight is lots less than a real katana.
If there's any other type, brand or store that you can recommend i
will really appreciate it.

Thanks for your time.


*That samurai 3000 katana looks so cheesy don't you think? lol.
